title: Lauryn Howlett
text:
Welcome!

As a recent Master's graduate from Colorado State University specializing in Sustainable Food Systems and Water Resources, I bring hands-on expertise in R programming, GIS, and sustainable land management. My academic and research experiences have equipped me to analyze complex environmental data, develop practical solutions for land and water stewardship, and contribute to climate resilience initiatives.

Growing up in Colorado's Rocky Mountains inspired my dedication to natural resource stewardship and conservation. I am passionate about understanding how land use practices influence ecosystem health and sustainability. My goal is to advance conservation efforts by applying data-driven insights to support sustainable development and ecosystem restoration.



Education
PSM in Ecosystem Science and Sustainability - Sustainable Food Systems (2024)
Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado
Graduate Certificate - Water Resources (2024)
Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado
BS in Ecosystem Science and Sustainability, Minor in Sustainable Energy (2021)
Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado

title: My Projects
text:
Poudre Valley Community Farms - Flores del Sol Bird and Soil Monitoring Protocols
View the story map here
Worked collaboratively with peers and the stakeholder, Poudre Valley Community Farms, to establish a monitoring protocol to measure the impact of Conservation Agriculture farming practices on soil health, water use, and bird populations over time.


Correlating Trends of Silica Concentrations within a Subalpine Watershed Using Long Term Data
For my senior honors thesis, I aimed to determine the SiO2 trends in the Loch Vale watershed (LVWS), Rocky Mountain National Park, from 1982 - 2017, and the direct and indirect relationships between SiO2 concentrations, hydrological patterns, and aquatic algae, especially diatoms. Loch Vale is a good place to explore trends in silica dynamics over time because it is undisturbed with respect to major land uses such as forest harvest or agriculture. Its high elevation location in Rocky Mountain National Park protects it from direct human interference, but influences from climate change and atmospheric deposition may have altered silica dynamics (Oleksy et al. 2020).  Specific questions I asked of the data were: If and how are silica concentrations over the specified timeframe changing? What are the drivers of change for silica concentrations? What is the relationship between discharge and silica? Is there a relationship between silica concentrations and diatoms during the open water season? 


Design and Collaborative Implementation of a Pollinator Habitat on a Colorado Front Range Farm
View the YEAH presentation here
Pollinators play a critical ecosystem role, transferring pollen for wildflowers and crops. We investigated methods and benefits of establishing native pollinator corridors through agriculture by conducting a literature review on a partner farm, soil, and native plant and pollinator species in Colorado. Collaborating with stakeholder farmers and a volunteer restoration organization, we designed an agricultural field optimized to support native pollinators and are implementing our design with the help of a volunteer crew. To maximize our impact, we created community education resources from our literature review. Incorporating pollination corridors will strengthen the local ecosystem and agriculture economy.
